ISBN 085883538
root.pub-comments: Harald Hammarström lists Green 2003 as the canonical source for this language family, therefore the composite tree is built mainly from his hypothesis. "Despite this array of dissimilarities, however, it is now clear that Mp [Murrinh-patha], far from being an isolate, is in fact closely related to its eastern neighbour Ngty [Ngan'gityemeri]; indeed I propose that the two language together make up the 'Southern Daly' subgroup" (Green 2003: 128).

child.alt-names: Garama, Garrama, Murrinh-Patha, Murinypata, Murinjpata, Murinbada, Murinjbada, Murinbata, Marri-wutha, Garramung, Murriny Patha, Murinbada, Karama, Garama, Karaman, Murinkura, Nagor, Nangu, Mariwada, Mariwuda
child.pub-comments: "Walsh (1976: 4) identifies three dialects of Mp [Murrinh-patha]: Murrinh-kura, Murrinh-rdiminin, and Murrinh-patha itself. Data presented here comes exclusively from the Murrinh-patha dialect; all three dialects are close, and there is no suggestion that they diverge grammatically in any significant way" (Green 2003: 130).

Aboriginal tribes of Australia, their terrain, environmental controls, distribution, limits, and proper names. With four sheet map. Berkeley & Canberra: University of California Press. , Dousset, Laurent. AusAnthrop: Research and resources on Aboriginal Australia. http://www.ausanthrop.net/index.php. (19 October, 2009.)
child.pub-comments: "A detailed reassessment of the genetic status of the two southern Daly languages has become possible only in recent years, with the availability of Reid's (1990) doctorate on Ngty [Ngam'gityemeri], which contains a full account of the verbal morphology for both extant dialects, Ngw [Ngan'giwumirri] and Ngan'gikurunggurr (Ngk)" (Green 2003: 130).
